article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: In 2016, chip giant Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) acquired artificial intelligence chip start-up Nervana Systems.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Nervana's technology was supposed to allow Intel to compete against graphics giant NVIDIA (NASDAQ: NVDA) in the market for processors that handle the training of neural networks.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text:
According to Intel, Nervana's dedicated neural network training chips were slated to provide "unprecedented compute density at an order of magnitude more computing power than today's state of the art [graphics processing units]."
Late last year, Intel announced that it would begin shipping its first Nervana Engine by the end of 2017 and that it was "thrilled to have Facebook (NASDAQ: FB) in close collaboration sharing technical insights as we bring this new generation of new AI hardware to market."
Just a few months later, Bloomberg reported that Facebook is working to develop its own hardware, likely for artificial intelligence and machine-learning workloads.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Here's why this could spell trouble for Intel's Nervana efforts.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Why build your own chips?

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: While a giant like Facebook can certainly afford the expense of building its own chips, the reality is that it's a non-trivial undertaking.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Facebook isn't in the business of building and selling chips to customers -- it's interested in making sure that the vast data center infrastructure that supports its platforms is as efficient as possible to keep its total cost of operating as low as possible.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: If a third-party company like, say, Intel is willing to do the work to build great solutions for this market (especially if it'd be hard to replicate the performance/efficiency of the third party solution), then it makes sense to simply use that third-party solution.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Moreover, when there are many chip vendors vying to build the best solutions possible, a buyer like Facebook is usually in good shape in terms of hardware pricing, too, as competition naturally brings lower prices.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text:
It generally makes sense for a company to build its own chips in the following scenarios:
A company thinks it can do a better job of building a product tailored to its own requirements than any third party could.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: A company wants a chip developed to run proprietary algorithms/techniques that it doesn't want to share with a third party for competitive reasons.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Although it's conceivable that the second point is a key factor in driving Facebook to explore building its own chips, my guess -- based on the fact that Facebook gave Intel permission to name drop it in the Nervana chip press release last year -- is that it's more of the first one.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Indeed, if Intel's Nervana chip is under-performing relative to the company's lofty claims (something that Facebook developing its own chips has me wondering about), and if the other dedicated machine-learning chip start-ups (there are a lot of them out there these days) can't deliver either, then it wouldn't be surprising for Facebook to think that its best chance of getting the hardware it needs is to build that hardware itself.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Who wins, here?

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Facebook may be designing its own chips, but it'll need a third party to manufacture them.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: While Intel has advertised chip manufacturing services of its own in the past, those efforts don't seem to have gained much traction.

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: I believe, then, that if Facebook is successful in deploying its own artificial intelligence/machine-learning chip, it'll likely tap contract chip manufacturing giant Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (NYSE: TSM) to manufacture the chips (since TSMC's manufacturing technology is arguably the best in the industry, and its track record is superb).

article_title: Facebook Inc.'s In-House AI Chip Is Bad News for Intel Corp.'s Nervana
sentence_text: Such orders wouldn't be a game changer for TSMC -- Facebook's order volumes for such a chip wouldn't be anywhere near those of, say, a mobile processor or even a merchant graphics processor -- but it'd be incremental revenue over the long term -- always a good thing.
